stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the session importing and tweaking a large batch of new 3-D models supplied by Biobak, most of them for Bowser’s office and other in-progress levels. Major time goes into redesigning interactive switches, refining textures and combiners, and chasing tool-chain bugs in Fast64. Smaller but important topics include N64 performance tuning, a discovery that the NEMU emulator can reproduce hardware crashes, and status updates on remaining levels.

development_findings.summary: Steel beam texture upgraded from CI4 (1-bit alpha) to RGBA16 with a separate alpha mask, giving markedly smoother edges.
development_findings.quote: Because we now have 8-bit alpha… we have much, much smoother edges here and it looks so much better.

development_findings.summary: Blue-coin switch completely redesigned: baked texture replaces vertex colors, size increased 1.5×, no ground-pound animation kept (5-frame change judged unnecessary).
development_findings.quote: A five-frame thing doesn’t need an animation… It’s so much better than the previous one.

development_findings.summary: Several levels currently crash real N64 due to floating-point exceptions (e.g., Goomba scale hitting zero); Kaze flags it as tedious but fixable.
development_findings.quote: Unfortunately, I found out that a lot of the levels have floating-point exceptions when you enter them right now on N64… it’s going to be annoying as fuck.

development_findings.summary: Render-time goal for Course 1 lowered from 26 ms to about 24.5 ms; nanosecond-level savings still pursued.
development_findings.quote: I think we can get it down to maybe 24.5.

development_findings.summary: Manual bounding-box entry still required for Fast64 ‘render area’; Kaze again requests an automatic calculator.
development_findings.quote: I’ve asked for a feature to automatically compute it so many times now.

development_findings.summary: Cap switches rebuilt: new high-res geometry, four colour variants, three in-between models replace scale-bone animation to avoid Fast64 armature bugs.
development_findings.quote: Making armatures with switch bones sucks… This is so much faster than making the bones.

development_findings.summary: NEMU emulator is confirmed to reproduce hardware crashes, opening a new, faster debugging workflow.
development_findings.quote: NEMU crashes here just like N64 would… Oh my god, that is going to save me so much time.

development_findings.summary: New Goomba model imports but exposes texture-sharing and colour-swap issues; logged for later fix.
development_findings.quote: The closed-eyes texture needs to change… I don’t think I can do this right now.

development_findings.summary: Decision to hard-code normal pipes into level geometry for ‘tiny’ but free performance gain.
development_findings.quote: I also think we’re gonna put all the normal pipes hard-coded into the level in the end… just for a tiny bit of performance.

development_findings.summary: Overall progress: about 4.5 regular levels, Bowser level, two extras, and three overworlds remain to be built.
development_findings.quote: There’s like four and a half levels left… and then the three overworlds.

context_findings.summary: Kaze studies MrBeast videos for marketing inspiration.
context_findings.quote: I actually study MrBeast’s videos like a fucking nerd… How can I implement this?

context_findings.summary: Personal scheduling tweak (new workout routine) almost let chat gaslight him about the day.
context_findings.quote: The gaslight almost worked because I usually bench on Fridays.

context_findings.summary: Philosophical stance on programming encapsulation: hates private variables, sees them as meaningless overhead.
context_findings.quote: Private variables are completely useless and should never exist. They mean nothing to the processor.

biobak.summary: Provided extensive new assets this stream: blue-coin switch, cap switches, fish, Goomba overhaul, coin texture, fire animation colours, 8-bit warp pipe, sludge ‘net peanut’ block.
Participates live, quickly iterates on feedback (contrast tweaks, model scale, animation ideas).
biobak.quote: Let me just do that real quick… Yeah, I think so too, Biobak.

zeina.summary: Zeina is working on Wiggler run/walk animations in parallel; her forthcoming ‘Quatrainian’ door animations will require level logic updates.
zeina.quote: I think I finally got Wiggler’s walk or run looking right… I wasn’t gonna bother with doors after Quatrainian animations are in because I have to change them then again anyway.

key_stories.title: Reinventing the Cap Switch
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Biobak scrap the vanilla cap switch, building a high-fidelity replacement with proper world lighting and colour variants. After struggling with Fast64’s bone system, they pivot to swapping whole models for each state, gaining reliability and speed.
key_stories.challenge: Original animation relied on buggy armature scale bones and looked dated.
key_stories.process: Tested bone scaling, argued pros/cons, then created three static intermediate models and colour-baked textures, manually set render bounds.
key_stories.outcome: A stable, visually superior switch that integrates with lighting and costs negligible performance.
key_stories.key_quote: Making armatures with switch bones sucks… This is so much faster than making the bones.

key_stories.title: Chasing the Combiner Bug
key_stories.summary: A new fire texture appeared as blank white in-game. Kaze suspected tool errors, rebuilt the combiner from scratch, and eventually found a single incorrect setting, restoring the intended look.
key_stories.challenge: Fire model rendered incorrectly despite appearing fine in Blender.
key_stories.process: Tested on two emulators, tweaked clamp/mirror settings, rewrote combiner line-by-line.
key_stories.outcome: Correct, vivid flame effect and a better understanding of Fast64 quirks.
key_stories.key_quote: There must be a combiner setting somewhere that fucked it up and I don’t know what the setting was.

key_stories.title: Discovering NEMU as a Crash Oracle
key_stories.summary: While testing the faulty flame, Kaze noticed NEMU crashing exactly like real hardware. This revelation means future low-level bug hunts can be done without constant EverDrive flashes.
key_stories.challenge: Hardware-only crashes were slow to reproduce and diagnose.
key_stories.process: Ran the ROM in NEMU, observed identical crash, realised the emulator mirrored hardware behaviour.
key_stories.outcome: Adopts NEMU for faster debugging pipeline.
key_stories.key_quote: NEMU crashes here just like N64 would… that is going to save me so much time.

open_questions.context: Swimming physics felt ‘really weird’; Kaze suspects a raycasting error underwater but didn’t investigate further.
questions: What specifically causes the underwater raycast malfunction?
How widespread is the issue across levels?
What is the planned fix and timeline?

open_questions.context: Several levels crash due to objects scaling to zero (e.g., Goomba).
questions: Which objects besides Goomba trigger FPEs?
Is a systemic safeguard being added?
Who is responsible for auditing all levels?

open_questions.context: New Goomba model broke closed-eye textures and colour swaps, placed on ‘later’ list.
questions: What is the concrete fix plan for shared textures?
Will texture packing changes affect memory budget?

open_questions.context: Aim to shave ~1.5 ms from Course 1 render time.
questions: What optimisations remain on the roadmap?
How will success be measured on hardware vs emulator?
Are there non-render bottlenecks still unprofiled?

open_questions.context: Kaze proposes embedding pipes directly for micro-optimisations.
questions: How much time does this realistically save?
Will it complicate future level edits or modding tools?
